Graphical abstract N-Zn-F coordinated triazine-based COF as an artificial SEI can induce synergistic effect of regulating electron cloud density and accelerating Li+ desolvation, which restrains dendrites growth and stables Li metal anode. The disorganized lithium dendrites and unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) severely impede the practical application of lithium metal batteries (LMBs). Herein, the N-Zn-F coordinated triazine-based covalent organic framework (TTA-COF-ZnF2) is fabricated for the first time as an artificial SEI layer on the surface of lithium metal anodes (LMAs) to handle these issues. Zn–N coordination in one-dimensional (1D) ordered COF can increase lithiophilic sites, reduce the Li-nucleation barrier, and regulate the Li+ local coordination environment by optimizing surface charge density around the Zn metal. The electron-rich state induced by strong electron-withdrawing F-groups constructs electronegative nanochannels, which trigger efficient Li+ desolvation. These beneficial attributes boost Li+ transfer, and homogenize Li+ flux, leading to uniform Li deposition. Besides, the lithiophilic triazine ring polar groups in TTA-COF-ZnF2 further facilitate the Li+ migration. The latent working mechanism of adjusting Li deposition behaviors and stabilizing LMAs for TTA-COF-ZnF2 is illustrated by detailed in-situ/ex-situ characterizations and density functional theory (DFT) calculations. As expected, TTA-COF-ZnF2-modified Li|Cu half cells deliver a higher Coulombic efficiency (CE) of 98.4% over 250 cycles and lower nucleation overpotential (11 mV) at 1 mA cm−2, while TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li symmetric cells display a long lifespan over 3785 h at 2 mA cm−2. The TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li|S full cells exert ultrahigh capacity retention of 81% (837 mA h g−1) after 600 cycles at 1C. Besides, the TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li|LFP full cells with a high loading of 7.1 mg cm−2 exert ultrahigh capacity retention of 89% (108 mAh g−1) after 700 cycles at 5C. This synergistic strategy in N-Zn-F coordinated triazine-based COF provides a new insight to regulate the uniform plating/stripping behaviors for developing ultra-stable and dendrite-free LMBs. Keywords Covalent organic framework N-Zn-F coordination Charge regulation Lithium metal anodes Dendrite-free 1 Introduction Lithium metal anodes (LMAs) possess unparalleled theoretical specific capacity (3860 mA h g−1) and the ultralow redox potential (−3.04 V vs standard hydrogen electrode), which have been recognized as the promising anode material to fulfill the high energy density requirement for rechargeable batteries [1–3]. However, anisotropic Li dendrites growth caused by heterogeneous Li deposition and unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) derived from irreversible interfacial parasitic reactions results in serious capacity decay and insufficient lifespan, thus, hindering the practical application of lithium metal batteries (LMBs) [4–6]. To date, extensive efforts have been made to suppress above mentioned drawbacks, such as constructing a stable artificial protection layer [7–14], developing new electrolyte additives [15–17], exploring solid-state electrolytes [18–21], designing 3D lithophilic host structure [22–24]. Among them, constructing artificial SEI on the Li metal surface is an efficacious strategy to compensate for the shortcomings of unfavorable interfacial reactions and induce Li deposition behaviors [25–27]. Whereas, how to screen a suitable material to fabricate artificial SEI remains an enormous challenge. Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are a new crystalline polymer material with the merits of permanent porosity, tunable functionalized skeleton, regular topology, and stable structure [28–31]. Attributing to these advantages, COFs have been providing a new platform for many fields, such as catalysis, gas adsorption, energy conversion, and storage [32–35]. Especially, when COFs are applied to LMBs, the ordered one-dimensional (1D) open channels can accelerate Li+ transport and homogenize Li+ flux [36]. Besides, the controllable pore size and devisable molecular structure are not only beneficial for highly selective Li+ migration but also can stabilize the performance of batteries by mitigating interfacial side reactions [37,38]. These features enable COF promising candidate for artificial SEI in LMBs. At present, several studies that fabricated COF artificial SEI in LMBs to inhibit dendrite growth have achieved remarkable results. Guo's team successively constructed sp2c-COF-Co, NO2-COF, and COF-CN-S artificial SEI. Benefitting from the confinement of sp2c-COF on single atom Co, the introduction of electron-withdrawing nitro groups and the customization of cyanide groups/polysulfide chains bi-functional active sites, respectively, these COF materials modified cells possessed excellent electrochemical performances, such as a low Li-nucleation overpotential of 8 mV, an enhanced Li+ transfer number of 0.78 and an enduring cycling life of 7500 h [39–41]. Li et al. in situ fabricated an artificial SEI configured with highly nitrogen-rich triazine-based COF. Attributing to multiple lithiophilic sites, the COF@Li symmetric cells displayed an ultra-long cycling stability over 8000 h [42]. Wang et al. developed a multi-component triazine COF with partially electronegative channels (4C-TA0.5TF0.5-CTF) to modulate the interface stability of LMAs [43]. The 4C-TA0.5TF0.5-CTF modified LiFePO4 full cells delivered a superior capacity of 116 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles at 5 C. Zheng et al. added LiI in triazine COF to prepare COF-LiI coating on a Li metal surface [44]. Ascribed to the improved mechanical strength and ion transport, the COF-LiI assembled symmetric cells could be stably cycled over 2500 times at 10 mA cm−2. However, most previously reported works either focused on introducing exogenous metals into the COF backbone alone or paid attention to tailoring organic functional groups in COF monomers to prevent Li dendrites growth. The investigations on simultaneously coordinating exogenous metals and introducing strong electronegative groups along the porous walls of triazine COF are still scarce, particularly for interfacial protection in the field of LMBs. Among the many metals, Zn appears excellent lithiophilicity [45,46], which can be used as nucleation seeds to supply additional lithiophilic sites that reduce the Li+ nucleation barrier and trigger homogeneous Li deposition. As for the electronegative groups, F-groups characterized by a maximum charge polarization capability [47,48], introducing it in the channels of COF can create permselective nanofluidic channels and play a function of ion sieves. Herein, N-Zn-F coordinated triazine-based COF (TTA-COF-ZnF2) is designed as an artificial SEI on LMAs surface to realize the target of dendrite-free, long-life LMBs. On one hand, Zn is coordinated with the N atoms of C=N (imine) units, which can improve the interfacial compatibility and regulate the local coordination environment of Li+ by optimizing the electron cloud density around the Zn metal, further rearrange the Li+ concentration on the anode surface and actuate uniform Li deposition. On the other hand, owning to the electrostatic repulsion interaction, strong electronegative F-groups anchored in the COF allow Li+ transport while blocking anion migration, further accelerating the dissociation of Li-ion pairs and minimizing electrolyte consumption. Additionally, the triazine rings with lone pair electron-rich structures and high nitrogen content in COF channels, can serve as a donor for intensely attracting Li+ and speeding up Li+ transfer. Originating from these positive advantages, TTA-COF-ZnF2 modified LMAs display preeminent electrochemical performances compared with TTA-COF@Li and bare Li. When implemented as an artificial SEI, TTA-COF-ZnF2 modified LMAs show outstanding cycle stability over 4000 h, preferable Coulombic efficiency (CE), and relatively low nucleation overpotential (11 mV). Furthermore, The TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li|S full cells exert ultrahigh capacity retention of 81% (837 mA h g−1) after 600 cycles at 1 C. TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li|LFP full cells exhibit prolonged cycle lifespan and superior capacity retention (a high initial capacity of 121 mA h g−1 and capacity retention of 89% over 700 cycles at 5 C). Accordingly, Density functional theory (DFT) calculations combined with in-situ/ex-situ characterizations are carried out to investigate the synergistic effect of N-Zn-F coordination and triazine-based COF on restraining the formation of Li dendrites, facilitating Li+ transportation, and mitigating electrolyte decomposition. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and apparatus The synthesis method for TTA-COF-ZnF2, the fabrication process for TTA-COF-ZnF2-based electrodes, the cells assembly and test, as well as the apparatus involved in this work, were all detailed in the Supporting Information. 2.2 Computational details In this study, all DFT calculations were performed using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [49]. The projector augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotential with the PBE generalized gradient approximation (GGA) exchange–correlation function was utilized in the computations [50,51]. The cutoff energy of the plane waves basis set was 500 eV and a Monkhorst-Pack mesh of 1 × 1 × 1 was used in K‐sampling. All structures were spin-polarized and all atoms were fully relaxed with the energy convergence tolerance of 10−5 eV per atom, and the final force on each atom was < 0.05 eV Å−1. The calculation of the HOMO and LUMO was conducted utilizing the VASPKIT computational toolkit. Subsequently, the molecular orbitals corresponding to the HOMO and LUMO were visually drawn with the help of the VESTA software. Finally, the adsorption energies (E ads) were calculated as E ads = E total − E A − E B, where E total, E A, and E B are the total energies of the optimized adsorbate/substrate system, the adsorbate in the structure, and the clean substrate, respectively. 3 Results and discussion It was hypothesized that TTA-COF-ZnF2 played a critical role in regulating surface charge transfer and Li+ migration. DFT was executed to verify this hypothesis and further comprehend Li+ adsorption and desolvation. As shown in Fig. 1 (a), the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) value (−4.369 eV) of TTA-COF-ZnF2 was higher than that of TTA-COF (−4.603 eV), indicating that TTA-COF-ZnF2 could energize more electrons. The lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) value (−3.015 eV) of TTA-COF-ZnF2 was lower than that of TTA-COF (−2.639 eV), confirming that TTA-COF-ZnF2 could obtain more electrons. Compared with TTA-COF, the lower HOMO-LUMO gap (ΔE = 1.354 eV) of TTA-COF-ZnF2 was favorable for raising electron conductivity and establishing a suitable Li+ local coordination environment. The above theoretical results indicated that TTA-COF-ZnF2 was a satisfactory material for regulating electronic distribution, expediting Li+ transfer, and inducing Li+ uniform deposition. Therefore, it was proposed to construct a TTA-COF-ZnF2-based artificial SEI to inhibit Li dendrites growth in this article (Fig. 1b, c). Firstly, triazine-based COF scaffold (denoted as TTA-COF) was synthesized by the aggregation of 4,4′4″-(1,3,5-triazine-2,4,6-triyl) trianiline (TTA) and 1,2-Acenaphthenequinone (Ace) monomers according to previous reports [52]. Subsequently, the TTA-COF-ZnF2 was obtained through a post-synthetic modification (PSM) approach with the introduction of zinc fluoride tetrahydrate. TTA-COF and TTA-COF-ZnF2 single frameworks were depicted in Fig. S1. Owing to the planar structure of TTA and Ace building blocks, the high π-π interactions between the adjacent layers were achieved, guaranteeing highly crystalline TTA-COF-ZnF2 (Fig. 2 a). The crystalline structure of TTA-COF-ZnF2 and TTA-COF was inspected by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD, Fig. 2b) analysis in collaboration with structural simulations. The characteristic peaks at 4.0°, 7.1°, 8.0°, 12.1°, and 14.7° of TTA-COF were ascribed to the (100), (110), (200), (210), and (120) facets, respectively, while the diffraction peak at about 25° originated from π-π stacking interaction between the adjacent layers and corresponded to the (001) plane [32]. In comparison to TTA-COF, a similar PXRD pattern could be detected for TTA-COF-ZnF2, revealing that the crystalline structure was still retained after Zn ions coordination. In addition, the experimental PXRD results were matched well with the simulated pattern of structural optimization, which again confirmed intact crystallinity of the obtained samples. A series of characterizations were executed on the TTA-COF and TTA-COF-ZnF2 to investigate the accuracy of the designed COF structure. Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR, Fig. 2c) spectra of TTA-COF and TTA-COF-ZnF2 exhibited a typical vibration band at 1643 cm−1 which might be attributed to the presence of an imine bond (C=N). Besides, a solid-state 13C nuclear magnetic resonance (13C NMR) test was performed. As shown in Fig. 2(d), the two peaks at 156.2 and 170.6 ppm in 13C NMR were assigned to the C=N in imine groups and C=N in the triazine ring, respectively, confirming the successful synthesis of triazine-based COF, consistent with the FT-IR results [52]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) investigation was carried out to estimate the coordination environment and ascertain the chemical states of Zn. The XPS spectrum of TTA-COF-ZnF2 manifested the presence of C, N, F, and Zn (Fig. S2a–c). The two peaks at 1044.4 and 1021.2 eV in the high-resolution Zn 2p XPS spectrum were assigned to the 2p 1/2 and 2p 3/2 of Zn2+ (Fig. S2d), respectively, which verified the coordination of Zn ions with the N atoms in C=N groups [52]. No signals were found for any other Zn species in TTA-COF-ZnF2, such as metallic Zn and ZnO. Moreover, as shown in N 1s XPS spectra (Fig. 2e), the N 1s signal band of TTA-COF-ZnF2 could be deconvoluted into two nitrogen configurations, involving imine-N at 399.8 eV and pyridinic-N at 398.7 eV [53]. Compared with pristine TTA-COF, a slight shift of the imine-N peak to higher binding energy could be detected in TTA-COF-ZnF2 due to the coordination of N atoms with Zn ions, which was consistent with literature reports [32,52]. The permanent porosities of TTA-COF and TTA-COF-ZnF2 were evaluated by N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms measurement at 77 K. As shown in Fig. 2(f) and Fig. S3(a), gas uptake increased sharply at low relative pressures (P/P 0 < 0.1) indicating the emergence of micropores. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of TTA-COF and TTA-COF-ZnF2 were 446.3 and 321.5 m2 g−1, respectively. The reduced surface area of TTA-COF-ZnF2 could be attributed to the ZnF2 partially occupying the interior cavities of the pristine COF [54]. The permanent pore sizes of both TTA-COF and TTA-COF-ZnF2 were calculated to be 0.95 nm using the non-local DFT model. The open ordered micropores of TTA-COF and TTA-COF-ZnF2 were favorable to the permeation of the electrolyte and the transport of Li+ in the nanochannels. Moreover, the thermal stability was also essential for practical application of COF based materials as artificial SEI. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, Fig. S3b) revealed that both TTA-COF and TTA-COF-ZnF2 behaved superior thermal stability in a nitrogen atmosphere up to 350℃. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) were utilized to investigate the microstructure of TTA-COF and TTA-COF-ZnF2. TTA-COF displayed a uniform rod-like structure with rough surface (Fig. S4a), which could be ascribed to the microcrystal growth and self-assembly process. As shown in Fig. S4(b, c) and Fig. 2(g), the TTA-COF-ZnF2 also displayed nanorod shapes with no structural collapse, indicating the Zn loading did not alter the TTA-COF microstructure. The energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping images of TTA-COF-ZnF2 manifested the homogeneous distribution of C, N, F and Zn elements (Fig. 2h), substantiating the incorporation of Zn element into TTA-COF. The corresponding Zn content in TTA-COF-ZnF2 matrix was determined to be 1.1 wt% by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) technique. The two diffraction rings in the selected area electron diffraction (SAED, Fig. 2i) pattern fitted well with (120) and (200) planes of TTA-COF-ZnF2, consisting with the PXRD results. In order to obtain uniform TTA-COF-ZnF2 layer on Li foil, different volume of TTA-COF-ZnF2 dispersion was dripped and the morphology of the coated layer was investigated. As shown in Fig. S5(a), when the dripping volume was less than 15 μL (mass loading: 1 mg mL−1), the TTA-COF-ZnF2 layer was not completely covered on the surface of Li foil. Besides, the TTA-COF-ZnF2 layer suffered from serious exfoliation or unevenness with the dripping volume excessing 60 μL (Fig. S5b). Figs. S5(c) and S6(a) show that the homogeneous artificial SEI layer could be observed with a dripping volume of 30 μL. Furthermore, the EDX mapping (Fig. S6a1–a4) clearly confirmed the uniform distribution of C, N, F, and Zn elements in the layer, demonstrating existence of TTA-COF-ZnF2. The cross-sectional image depicted that the TTA-COF-ZnF2 layer with a thickness of 9 μm was tightly attached to Li, indicating satisfactory adhesion between Li foil and TTA-COF-ZnF2 (Fig. S6b). Additionally, the interfacial compatibility between TTA-COF-ZnF2 and electrolyte was evaluated by contact angle experiments at macroscopic-level (Fig. S7). The contact angle of TTA-COF-ZnF2 (14.7°) was much smaller than that of bare Li (36.4°), indicating its better wettability and compatibility with the polar electrolyte. According to Fig. S8, the even TTA-COF-ZnF2 layer could be coated on Cu foil by similar fabrication strategy. To demonstrate the feasibility of TTA-COF-ZnF2 as the artificial SEI for LMAs, Li|Cu half cells and Li|Li symmetrical cells were assembled to evaluate the lithium storage properties. The CE defined as a ratio of Li stripping to plating capacity per cycle, is an important indicator for assessing the utilization of lithium metal during the repeated charge/discharge process. As exhibited in Fig. 3 (a), Li|TTA-COF-ZnF2@Cu half cells had a remarkable stability and superior CE value of 98.4% over 250 cycles at 1 mA cm−2/1 mA h cm−2, which was obviously better than those of Li|TTA-COF@Cu and Li|bare Cu (about 145 and 81 cycles, respectively). When the current density and deposition capacity were set as 0.5 mA cm−2/0.5 mA h cm−2 and 0.5 mA cm−2/1 mA h cm−2 (Fig. S9a, b), Li|TTA-COF-ZnF2@Cu half cells still displayed preferable cycling stability (204 and 260 cycles, respectively), while Li|TTA-COF@Cu and Li|bare Cu exhibited inferior cycle lifespan. Additionally, the voltage–time curves of the Li|TTA-COF-ZnF2@Cu were tested at 1 mA cm−2/1 mA h cm−2. As shown in Fig. 3(b) and Fig. S9(c–f), apart from the higher initial polarization voltage of TTA-COF-ZnF2@Cu (58 mV) than bare Cu (42 mV) during pre-activation, the voltage levels of TTA-COF-ZnF2 were sustained at about 20 mV in subsequent cycles, suggesting that the artificial SEI layer could hardly be damaged during the plating/stripping process. Disappointingly, a dramatic voltage fluctuation could be observed for TTA-COF@Cu (33, 27 and 25 mV at 50th, 100th and 150th cycles, respectively) and bare Cu (35, 28 and 32 mV at 30th, 60th and 90th cycles, respectively) half cells as the cycle went on. This phenomenon was primarily caused by the cracking and reconstruction of SEI, resulting in the formation of disorganized Li dendrites and needless consumption of electrolyte [55]. Besides, the overpotential during the Li deposition process was estimated through the nucleation overpotential and mass transfer-controlled plateau potential (Fig. 3c). The nucleation overpotentials of Li|TTA-COF-ZnF2@Cu, Li|TTA-COF@Cu and Li|bare Cu were 11, 23 and 38 mV at 1 mA cm−2/1 mA h cm−2, respectively. The lowest nucleation overpotential of Li|TTA-COF-ZnF2@Cu elucidated that Li nucleation growth favored to be relatively fast, widely scattered, and evenly smooth, which was helpful to the suppression of whisker-like Li formation during reduplicative cycles. What’s more, the Li|TTA-COF-ZnF2@Cu delivered a much lower mass-transfer overpotential (12 mV) than Li|TTA-COF@Cu (17 mV) and Li|bare Cu (24 mV), respectively. All the above-mentioned results suggested that TTA-COF-ZnF2 artificial SEI not only featured an extended cycling stability with high CE but also prominently reduced nucleation energy barrier and accelerated Li+ migration. To quantitatively evaluate Li+ conducting capability of TTA-COF-ZnF2, the t Li + of symmetric cells was determined by the Bruce-Vincent method [56]. The t Li + increased from 0.35 for the bare Li to 0.42 for TTA-COF@Li, and then to 0.67 for the TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li (Fig. 3d, Fig. S10, Table S1). A highest t Li + of TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li could be attributed to electron-rich channels constructed by highly electronegative F-groups in the COF with ordered permanent micropores, which impeded the transport of anions and expedite Li+ interfacial migration. Exchange current density regarded as another crucial indicator to characterize the interfacial ion transport kinetics, was measured to assess the diffusion rate of Li+. As shown in Fig. 3(e), the exchange current density of TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li was 0.30 mA cm−2, which was higher than TTA-COF@Li (0.21 mA cm−2) and bare Li (0.09 mA cm−2), respectively, manifesting rapid Li+ transfer at the electrode/electrolyte interface of the former. To further probe the superiority of TTA-COF-ZnF2 as an artificial SEI on the long-term Li plating/stripping process, the Li|Li symmetric cells were measured by galvanostatic charge/discharge test. As shown in Fig. 3(f), the TTA-COF-ZnF2 modified symmetric cell exhibited fulfilling cycling stability with an extremely low overpotential of 13 mV over 1850 h at 0.5 mA cm−2/0.5 mA h cm−2. Conversely, the bare Li and TTA-COF@Li presented severe voltage fluctuations after 500 and 750 h cycles, respectively. The increased overpotential could be attributed to the amassment of inactive Li as the cycle time lengthens, leading to enlarged impedance and the gradual deterioration of symmetric cells performance. When cycling at 1 mA cm−2/1 mA h cm−2, the TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li exhibited stable overpotential of 23 mV more than 4000 h (Fig. 3g). However, the bare Li and TTA-COF@Li showed sudden voltage increase after 450 and 600 h, respectively. Once surpassing this time, the polarization voltage of bare Li and TTA-COF@Li will sharply increase until the cells are out of service. According to Fig. 3(h), similar long-term cycling performance of the three symmetric cells could be observed at a current density/stationary capacity of 2 mA cm−2/2 mA h cm−2. Notably, the TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li could be stable for 3785 h with low overpotential (30 mV), far longer than bare Li and TTA-COF@Li. Even working at 4 mA cm−2 with a capacity of 2 mA h cm−2, the TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li still could operate for 1600 h (Fig. S11), without any sign of being out of work. The improved long-term cycling stability of TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li symmetric cell showed clear preponderance among previously reported artificial SEI layers in LMAs (Table S2). Meanwhile, the rate performances of the obtained symmetrical cells were examined at 1 mA h cm−2 with varied current densities (Fig. 3i). When the current densities increased from 0.25 to 6 mA cm−2, both the bare Li and TTA-COF@Li cells showed an enormous raising in polarization voltage, revealing sluggish kinetics and a dendrite/dead Li-eroded LMAs surface. Impressively, TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li had relatively constant cycling tendencies and displayed smaller voltage hysteresis throughout the entire process, further verifying that the TTA-COF-ZnF2 derived artificial SEI was robust enough to relieve dendrite stress and expedite Li+ transfer. The cycle-dependent electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was recorded to supervise the interfacial variation in Fig. S12. Compared with bare Li anode, The TTA-COF-ZnF2 and TTA-COF modified electrodes exhibited larger interfacial resistance during the pre-activation process owning to the inherent poor electrical conductivity of COF and the realignment of Li+ migration channels occurring at the electrolyte/COF interface. Impressively, with the cycle number increasing, the significantly depressed interfacial resistance of TTA-COF-ZnF2 modified symmetric cells convincingly elucidated that the TTA-COF-ZnF2 artificial SEI layer was awarded stable and rapid Li+ migration capability. To better unveil the superiority of the TTA-COF-ZnF2 artificial SEI layer to inhibit Li dendrites, the Li deposition morphologies were further investigated by SEM analysis of symmetric cells under various cycles at 1 mA cm−2/1 mA h cm−2. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), the absence of lithophilic sites for bare Li rendered it awkward to achieve effective Li+ transfer kinetics, which resulted in the fluffy and porous Li deposition after 50 cycles. The moss-like Li dendrites and obvious cracks appeared on the electrode surface in the subsequent cycles (Fig. 4b, c). This terrible noncompact structure could promote the destruction of the natural SEI, accumulation of side reaction products, and continuous electrolyte depletion, bringing about large fluctuations of polarization voltage and increased interface resistance for the bare Li symmetric cell [57,58]. For TTA-COF@Li and TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li, the dense electrode morphologies could be detected after 50 cycles, implying that the ordered micropores and triazine ring polar lithiophilic groups were able to suppress Li dendrites growth by supplying fast and directional Li+ transportation channels (Fig. 4d, g). The rough interface and aggregation of “dead” Li appeared on the TTA-COF@Li electrode after 100 cycles (Fig. 4e, f). However, TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li electrode displayed an extremely compact and smooth surface even after 200 cycles (Fig. 4i), signifying the positive effect of Zn metal on guiding homogenous Li deposition in long-term cycles. Moreover, the corresponding cross-sectional SEM image and PXRD patterns of the TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li electrode demonstrated no structural collapse and phase changes after repeated plating/stripping process, again verifying its superior stability (Fig. S13). The synergistic effects of Zn–N coordination and strong electronegative F-groups could be conducive to overcoming the heterogeneous nucleation barrier, homogenizing Li+ flux, and regulating the local coordination environment of Li+ by optimizing the electron cloud density around the Zn metal, inducing uniform Li deposition. In-situ optical microscopy was employed to dynamically investigate the growth behaviors of Li dendrites in the plating/stripping process. The digital photographs of the cross-sections for the symmetric cells imposed the same current density of 2 mA cm−2 at different time periods. As shown in Fig. 4(j), the formation of Li dendrites could be firstly observed after plating for 5 min in a bare Li symmetric cell, and then a few mossy dendrites subsequently appeared after 10 min, finally, uncontrollable dendrites were detected with the plating time of 30 min. Grievous dendrite growth could raise the danger of short-circuiting and cause great safety hazards for LMBs [59]. Compared with bare Li, appreciable Li dendrites had hardly been found on the TTA-COF-ZnF2 modified LMAs during the whole plating process for 30 min, which again proved the synergistic effects of Zn–N coordination and F-groups on inhibition of Li dendrites (Fig. 4k). Afterward, the SEI layer was analyzed by XPS to further research the chemical composition of the LMAs surface after cycling for 400 h at 1 mA cm−2/1 mA h cm−2. In general, the generated SEI of LMAs mainly consists of inorganic (Li2CO3, LiF and Li2S/Li2S2 et al.) and organic (RCO2Li, ROCO2Li, –CF3 et al.) compounds [60,61]. As shown in Fig. 5 (a–d) and Fig. S14, based on the fitting results, several fragments of C–C, C–O–C, O–C=O in C 1s, and C=O, C–O in O 1s were detected on the three electrodes surface, which were assigned to the decomposition of ether-based solvent molecules during the SEI formation [62]. Li 1s, F 1s, N 1s, and S 2p spectra were tested to explore the component evolution of TFSI−. The peaks of C–F in C 1s and F 1s corresponded to the –CF3 in TFSI−. Significantly, the strongest C–F peak intensity and weakest LiF peak intensity in the TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li revealed that the least TFSI− anions were reduced into LiF than those of bare Li and TTA-COF@Li electrodes. Besides, the binding energy of N 1s spectra at 397.2, 399.3, 403.8 and 407.5 eV could be assigned to Li3N, S–N, LiN x O y, and –NO3, respectively, which could be originated from the decomposition of LiTFSI and electrolyte additives (LiNO3). Compared with TTA-COF@Li and bare Li electrodes, the increasing S–N peak intensity and reducing Li3N peak intensity in TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li declared that a little LiTFSI and LiNO3 were reduced to Li3N. What’s more, the evidently decreased peak intensities in S 2p and Li 1s related with Li2NSO2CF3, Li2S/Li2S2, and LiF products of TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li also similarly implied the efficient alleviation to the depletion of TFSI−. Therefore, the TTA-COF-ZnF2 artificial SEI layer could restrain electrolyte decomposition, efficaciously adjust the interfacial composition, and lengthen the battery lifespan. DFT calculations were used to investigate the superior Li affinity of TTA-COF-ZnF2 and the corresponding desolvation mechanism. The Li+ coordination geometrical configuration results are exhibited in Fig. 5(e). The adsorption energy between Li+ and TTA-COF-ZnF2, TTA-COF, 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME), 1,3-dioxolane (DOL), TFSI− was calculated to be −3.548, −3.135, −1.715, −1.506 and −2.520 eV, respectively, suggesting TTA-COF-ZnF2 possessed the privilege of preferring to attract Li+ in the competition of forming solvation sheath. It may originate from the relatively negative charge agglomeration caused by the electron-withdrawing F-groups. This speculation was verified by the theoretical calculation of electron density differences. As shown in Fig. 5(f), the TTA-COF-ZnF2 owned a more negative electrostatic environment than TTA-COF, which can effectively regulate electron distribution and speed Li+ migration. Meanwhile, the adsorption energy of DOL-TTA-COF-ZnF2 and DME-TTA-COF-ZnF2 was 0.275 and 0.394 eV, respectively. Positive adsorption energy value indicated that TTA-COF-ZnF2 could repel solvent molecules (DOL and DME). Subsequently, the desolvation of Li+ for TTA-COF-ZnF2 would be easily achieved under such a high Li+ affinity capability and strong repulsion against solvent molecules, thus, accelerating interfacial migration of Li+ at electrolyte/electrode surface. In addition, the higher adsorption energy value of 1.627 eV between TFSI− and TTA-COF-ZnF2 than that of TTA-COF demonstrated a considerable ability to repel TFSI− anions, favorable for Li-ion pairs dissociation [63]. According to 7Li solid-state NMR measurement (Fig. S15), the chemical shift of TTA-COF-ZnF2@LiTFSI changed from −1.21 to 0.31 ppm, indicating remarkably enhanced deshielding effect caused by the electron-withdrawing F-groups, further proved that TTA-COF-ZnF2 induced the dissociation of LiTFSI at the electrode surface. The strong energetic attraction for Li+, repulsion against solvent molecules, and ion-pairs dissociation of TTA-COF-ZnF2 could induce the fast interfacial migration kinetic behaviors of Li+, accordant with a higher Li+ transfer number of TTA-COF-ZnF2 modified symmetric cells. To confirm the practical application potential of TTA-COF-ZnF2 modified LMAs, full cells pairing with sulfur (S), LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 (NCM811) cathodes were assembled and evaluated. As exhibited in Fig. 6 (a), the TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li|S full cell demonstrated a high initial capacity of 1034 mAh g−1 and a satisfactory capacity retention of 81% even after 600 cycles at 1 C. However, TTA-COF@Li|S and bare Li|S full cells exhibited drastic capacity recession with inferior capacity retention of 47% and 41% respectively at the same test condition. Furthermore, TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li|NCM811 full cell performed a much higher reversible capacity (153 mAh g−1) and capacity retention (91%) than those of TTA-COF@Li|NCM811 (130 mAh g−1, 78%, respectively) and bare Li|NCM811 (110 mA h g−1, 67%, respectively) after 200 cycles at 0.5 C (Fig. 6b). Even operating at 1 C for 180 cycles, the TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li|NCM811 full cell still presented preferable capacity retention of 87% (Fig. S16a). The TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li|LFP was also assembled and can achieve a capacity of 113.4 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles at 1 C (Fig. S16b). Importantly, a harsh condition (cycling at 5 C for 700 cycles with a high loading of 7.1 mg cm−2) were applied to demonstrate the feasible use of TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li as the anode in LMBs. As expected, the TTA-COF-ZnF2|LFP possessed a higher capacity retention of 89% than TTA-COF@Li|LFP (71%) and bare Li|LFP (53%), indicating great potential in practical applications (Fig. 6c). The rapid capacity degradation of bare Li and TTA-COF@Li full cells might be ascribed to the depressed Li utilization because of the uncontrolled dendrite growth on the anode surface. Fig. 6(d–f) and Fig. S17 showed the charge/discharge curves of all full cells. Reduced polarization voltage and enhanced specific capacities of TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li-based full cells reflected the fast charge-transfer kinetics during Li plating/stripping. As shown in Fig. 6(g) and Fig. S18(a), the rate performances of the full cells were also tested, the TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li|S full cell delivered reversible capacities of 1482, 1252, 1115, 1008 and 885 mA h g−1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0 and 1.5 C, respectively, which largely surpassed those of TTA-COF@Li|S (1388, 1112, 1002, 910 and 797 mAh g−1) and bare Li|S (1358, 1042, 916, 831 and 688 mA h g−1). Similarly, the rate performances of TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li|NCM811 and TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li|LFP full cells were apparently superior to bare Li and TTA-COF@Li full cells (Fig. 6h, i, and Fig. S18b, c). The overwhelming merits of high reversibility capacity, small polarization, and extended lifespan indicated the indispensable role of TTA-COF-ZnF2 as an artificial SEI layer in stabilizing LMAs, homogenizing Li+ flux on electrode/electrolyte interface, and facilitating deposition kinetics. 4 Conclusions In summary, a unique artificial SEI layer of N-Zn-F coordinated triazine-based COF (TTA-COF-ZnF2) was designed for the first time to accelerate Li+ transfer, prevent Li dendrite formation and strengthen interfacial stability on LMAs surface. Ingeniously, the synergistic effect of Zn–N coordination and high electronegative F-groups in TTA-COF-ZnF2 could effectually adjust the local electron structure to build a negative electron environment, thus reducing Li+ heterogeneous nucleation barrier and enhancing dissociation capacity of Li+ from the electrolyte, which had been proved by the DFT calculations and various in-situ/ex-situ experimental observations. Additionally, the ordered 1D nanochannels along with lithiophilic triazine ring polar groups provided a directional fast Li+ transport path, thereby effectively homogenizing the Li+ flux and facilitating Li+ diffusion. With such an artificial SEI layer, the assembled Li|TTA-COF-ZnF2@Cu half cells performed a high CE of 98.4% over 250 cycles and low nucleation overpotential (11 mV) at 1 mA cm−2. Simultaneously, TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li-based symmetric cells displayed an ultra-stable cycle performance of more than 3785 h at 2 mA cm−2. More importantly, the assembled TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li|S, TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li|LFP and TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li|NCM811 full cells maintain superior cycling stability. The rational design of TTA-COF-ZnF2 as an artificial SEI layer will shed new light on promoting the synergistic concept of interface protection and inspire the further development of stable, dendrite-free LMBs. coredata.dc:description: The disorganized lithium dendrites and unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) severely impede the practical application of lithium metal batteries (LMBs). Herein, the N-Zn-F coordinated triazine-based covalent organic framework (TTA-COF-ZnF2) is fabricated for the first time as an artificial SEI layer on the surface of lithium metal anodes (LMAs) to handle these issues. Zn–N coordination in one-dimensional (1D) ordered COF can increase lithiophilic sites, reduce the Li-nucleation barrier, and regulate the Li+ local coordination environment by optimizing surface charge density around the Zn metal. The electron-rich state induced by strong electron-withdrawing F-groups constructs electronegative nanochannels, which trigger efficient Li+ desolvation. These beneficial attributes boost Li+ transfer, and homogenize Li+ flux, leading to uniform Li deposition. Besides, the lithiophilic triazine ring polar groups in TTA-COF-ZnF2 further facilitate the Li+ migration. The latent working mechanism of adjusting Li deposition behaviors and stabilizing LMAs for TTA-COF-ZnF2 is illustrated by detailed in-situ/ex-situ characterizations and density functional theory (DFT) calculations. As expected, TTA-COF-ZnF2-modified Li|Cu half cells deliver a higher Coulombic efficiency (CE) of 98.4% over 250 cycles and lower nucleation overpotential (11 mV) at 1 mA cm−2, while TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li symmetric cells display a long lifespan over 3785 h at 2 mA cm−2. The TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li|S full cells exert ultrahigh capacity retention of 81% (837 mA h g−1) after 600 cycles at 1C. Besides, the TTA-COF-ZnF2@Li|LFP full cells with a high loading of 7.1 mg cm−2 exert ultrahigh capacity retention of 89% (108 mAh g−1) after 700 cycles at 5C. This synergistic strategy in N-Zn-F coordinated triazine-based COF provides a new insight to regulate the uniform plating/stripping behaviors for developing ultra-stable and dendrite-free LMBs.
